title: 3. Fitting models and making predictions
text: exemplify fitting predicting functions, going use data Johnson, Diggle, Giorgi (2020) again1. First, code chunk , load data convert smile compatible classes. Since toy example, going generate 500 points grid MSOA data 5 points polygon LSOA data. map shows LEB observed MSOAs.  map displays IMD observed LSOAs.
code: data(liv_msoa) data(liv_lsoa)  ## workaround for compatibility with different PROJ versions st_crs(liv_msoa) <-     st_crs(liv_msoa)$input  st_crs(liv_lsoa) <-     st_crs(liv_lsoa)$input  ## msoa to spm spm_msoa <-     sf_to_spm(sf_obj = liv_msoa,               n_pts  = 500,               type   = "regular",               by_polygon = FALSE,               poly_ids = "msoa11cd",               var_ids  = "leb_est")  ## lsoa to spm spm_lsoa <-     sf_to_spm(sf_obj = liv_lsoa,               n_pts  = 5,               type   = "regular",               by_polygon = TRUE,               poly_ids = "lsoa11cd",               var_ids  = "imdscore") ggplot(data = liv_msoa,        aes(fill = leb_est)) +     geom_sf(color = 1, lwd = .1) +     scale_fill_viridis_c(option = "H") +     theme_minimal() ggplot(data = liv_lsoa,        aes(fill = imdscore)) +     geom_sf(color = 1, lwd = .1) +     scale_fill_viridis_c(option = "H") +     theme_minimal()

what: Fit at MSOA, prediction at LSOA
title: 3. Fitting models and making predictions
text: Using starting parameters \(\alpha = 70\) (average \(Y\)), \(\omega = 1\) (can seen nugget effect), \(\sigma^2\) (variance parameter powered exponential family), \(\phi = 1\) (paramter controls range os spatial dependence, 1 represents 1_km_). going compute Maximum Likelihood estimates considering Powered Exponential covariance function data, \(\kappa = 1.5\)2. Note , important inputing vector named vector, functions track parameters names. seconds, get Results. Now, can use function summary_spm_fit get summary results. function prints table containing estimates, standard errors, 1 - sig confidence interval based asymptotic normality MLEs. function also prints message indicating optimization algorithm converged3. Finally, now going perform predictions LEB LSOA level. , use function predict_spm. x argument gives sf want make predictions according sbm_obj, represents estimated parameters. Now, take look remaining arguments. last two, analogous seen function sf_to_spm. concerning grid generated study region, now going make predicitons grid. set 2500 “approximate” continuous region4. argument .aggregate set TRUE, computes predictions polygons input x (case liv_lsoa). function also works input sf object POINT geometries. objects returned function pred_lsoa lists following elements: 1) mu_pred - vector predicted average location generated grid; 2) sig_pred variance covariance matrix associated grid; 3) predictions (standard errors) organized sf object facilitate visualization predictions (almost) continuous space; 4) pred_agg returned set .aggregate = TRUE. last one contains predictions standard erros integrated “new regions”. Now, let’s make data manipulation make visualization look nicer. going stack data make easier plot together using ggplot2. next map whos predictions.  next one displays standard errors predictions. Clearly, less variability neighborhoods small polygons.
code: theta_st_msoa <- c("phi" = 1)  fit_msoa <-     fit_spm(x = spm_msoa,             theta_st = theta_st_msoa,             model = "pexp",             kappa = 1,             apply_exp = TRUE,             opt_method = "L-BFGS-B",             control   = list(maxit = 500)) summary_spm_fit(fit_msoa, sig = .05) #>  #>  optimization algorithm converged: yes  #>  #>     par   estimate        se               ci #> 1    mu 75.9086328 0.7509821 [74.437; 77.381] #> 2 sigsq 23.4456538 4.2920431 [15.033; 31.858] #> 3   phi  0.7552022 0.1917379   [0.379; 1.131] pred_lsoa <- predict_spm(x = liv_lsoa, spm_obj = fit_msoa,                          .aggregate = TRUE, n_pts = 2500,                          type = "regular") aux_viz1 <- vector(mode   = "list",                    length = 4)  aux_viz1[[1]] <- transform(pred_lsoa$pred_grid["mu_pred"],                            surface  = "continuous",                            variable = "prediction") names(aux_viz1[[1]])[1] <- "value" aux_viz1[[2]] <- transform(pred_lsoa$pred_grid["se_pred"],                            surface  = "continuous",                            variable = "se") names(aux_viz1[[2]])[1] <- "value" aux_viz1[[3]] <- transform(pred_lsoa$pred_agg["mu_pred"],                            surface  = "aggregated",                            variable = "prediction") names(aux_viz1[[3]])[1] <- "value" aux_viz1[[4]] <- transform(pred_lsoa$pred_agg["se_pred"],                            surface  = "aggregated",                            variable = "se") names(aux_viz1[[4]])[1] <- "value"  aux_viz1 <- do.call("rbind", aux_viz1)  ggplot(data = aux_viz1[aux_viz1$variable == "prediction",],        aes(fill  = value,            color = value)) +     geom_sf(data = st_geometry(pred_lsoa$pred_agg), color = 1,             lwd = .1, inherit.aes = FALSE) +     geom_sf(pch = 15) +     scale_fill_viridis_c(option = "H") +     scale_color_viridis_c(option = "H") +     guides(color = "none") +     facet_wrap(surface ~ .) +     theme_bw() ggplot(data = aux_viz1[aux_viz1$variable == "se",],        aes(fill  = value,            color = value)) +     geom_sf(data = st_geometry(pred_lsoa$pred_agg), color = 1,             lwd = .1, inherit.aes = FALSE) +     geom_sf(pch = 15) +     scale_fill_viridis_c(option = "H") +     scale_color_viridis_c(option = "H") +     guides(color = "none") +     facet_wrap(surface ~ .) +     theme_bw() rm(aux_viz1, pred_lsoa, fit_msoa) invisible(gc(full = TRUE))

what: Fit at LSOA, predict at MSOA
title: 3. Fitting models and making predictions
text: Using starting parameters \(\alpha = 25\) (average \(Y\)), \(\omega = 1\) (can seen nugget effect), \(\sigma^2\) (variance parameter powered exponential family), \(\phi = 1\) (paramter controls range os spatial dependence, 1 represents 1_km_). going compute Maximum Likelihood estimates considering Matern covariance function data, \(\kappa = 2.5\). seconds, get Results. Now, can use function summary_sspm_fit summarise estimated parameters. Now going perform predictions IMD MSOA level. Since now process pretty much exam, explanation shorter. Now, let’s make data manipulation . Note , predictions variable  next one displays standard errors predictions.
code: theta_st_lsoa <-     c("phi" = 1)  fit_lsoa <-     fit_spm(x = spm_lsoa,             theta_st = theta_st_lsoa,             model = "matern",             kappa = .5,             apply_exp = TRUE,             opt_method = "L-BFGS-B",             control   = list(maxit = 500)) summary_spm_fit(fit_lsoa, sig = .05) #>  #>  optimization algorithm converged: yes  #>  #>     par    estimate          se                 ci #> 1    mu  39.7431355  3.13052877   [33.607; 45.879] #> 2 sigsq 573.0723501 59.35735535 [456.734; 689.411] #> 3   phi   0.6328429  0.08618022     [0.464; 0.802] pred_msoa <- predict_spm(x = liv_msoa, spm_obj = fit_lsoa,                          .aggregate = TRUE, n_pts = 2500,                          type = "regular") aux_viz2 <- vector(mode   = "list",                    length = 4)  aux_viz2[[1]] <- transform(pred_msoa$pred_grid["mu_pred"],                            surface  = "continuous",                            variable = "prediction") names(aux_viz2[[1]])[1] <- "value" aux_viz2[[2]] <- transform(pred_msoa$pred_grid["se_pred"],                            surface  = "continuous",                            variable = "se") names(aux_viz2[[2]])[1] <- "value" aux_viz2[[3]] <- transform(pred_msoa$pred_agg["mu_pred"],                            surface  = "aggregated",                            variable = "prediction") names(aux_viz2[[3]])[1] <- "value" aux_viz2[[4]] <- transform(pred_msoa$pred_agg["se_pred"],                            surface  = "aggregated",                            variable = "se") names(aux_viz2[[4]])[1] <- "value"  aux_viz2 <- do.call("rbind", aux_viz2)  ggplot(data = aux_viz2[aux_viz2$variable == "prediction",],        aes(fill  = value,            color = value)) +     geom_sf(data = st_geometry(pred_msoa$pred_agg), color = 1,             lwd = .1, inherit.aes = FALSE) +     geom_sf(pch = 15) +     scale_fill_viridis_c(option = "H") +     scale_color_viridis_c(option = "H") +     guides(color = "none") +     facet_wrap(surface ~ .) +     theme_bw() ggplot(data = aux_viz2[aux_viz2$variable == "se",],        aes(fill  = value,            color = value)) +     geom_sf(data = st_geometry(pred_msoa$pred_agg), color = 1,             lwd = .1, inherit.aes = FALSE) +     geom_sf(pch = 15) +     scale_fill_viridis_c(option = "H") +     scale_color_viridis_c(option = "H") +     guides(color = "none") +     facet_wrap(surface ~ .) +     theme_bw()

title: 3. Fitting models and making predictions
text: Johnson, Olatunji, Peter Diggle, Emanuele Giorgi. 2020. “Dealing Spatial Misalignment Model Relationship Deprivation Life Expectancy: Model-Based Geostatistical Approach.” International Journal Health Geographics 19 (1): 1–13.

title: 1. Converting sf objects to spm
text: Gelfand, Alan E, Li Zhu, Bradley P Carlin. 2001. “Change Support Problem Spatio-Temporal Data.” Biostatistics 2 (1): 31–45. Johnson, Olatunji, Peter Diggle, Emanuele Giorgi. 2020. “Dealing Spatial Misalignment Model Relationship Deprivation Life Expectancy: Model-Based Geostatistical Approach.” International Journal Health Geographics 19 (1): 1–13. Moraga, Paula, Susanna M Cramb, Kerrie L Mengersen, Marcello Pagano. 2017. “Geostatistical Model Combined Analysis Point-Level Area-Level Data Using Inla Spde.” Spatial Statistics 21: 27–41. Pebesma, Edzer. 2018. “Simple Features R: Standardized Support Spatial Vector Data.” R Journal 10 (1): 439–46. https://doi.org/10.32614/RJ-2018-009. Wickham, Hadley. 2011. “Ggplot2.” Wiley Interdisciplinary Reviews: Computational Statistics 3 (2): 180–85. Wilson, Katie, Jon Wakefield. 2020. “Pointless Spatial Modeling.” Biostatistics 21 (2): e17–e32.

title: 2. Spatial covariance functions
text: Diggle, PJ, Paulo Justiniano Ribeiro. 2007. “Model-Based Geostatistics (Springer Series Statistics).” , 51–56. Springer. Eddelbuettel, Dirk, Conrad Sanderson. 2014. “RcppArmadillo: Accelerating R High-Performance C++ Linear Algebra.” Computational Statistics & Data Analysis 71: 1054–63.

title: 4. Theory
text: Let \(\{ U(\mathbf{x}) \,:\, x \D \subset \mathbb{R}^2 \}\) (\(D\) whole region study, tipically city) stationary isotropic Gaussian Random Field (Rue Held 2005) mean constant equal zero space covariance function \(C(h; \mathbf{\theta})\), \(h\) euclidean distance two given points within \(D\), \(\mathbf{\theta}\) vector parameters controling spatial covariance structure process. Now, let \(\mathbf{Y}\) random variable observed partition \(D\) defined \(= \{A_1, \dots, A_n \}\). , define \[ Y( A_i ) = \alpha + U( A_i ) + \epsilon_i, \, = 1, ..., n, \] \[ U ( A_i ) = \frac{ 1 }{ \lvert A_i \rvert } \int_{A_i} U ( x ) \, dx, \] \(\epsilon_i \overset{iid}{\sim} N(0, \omega)\). Also, assume \(\epsilon \perp U\). expected value \(Y( A_i )\) \[ E[ Y ( A_i  )  ] = \alpha, \] variance/covarianca matrix given follows \[\begin{align*} Cov[ Y ( A_i ), Y ( A_j ) ] & = Cov[\alpha + U( A_i ) + \epsilon_i, \alpha + U( A_j ) + \epsilon_j] \\ & = Cov[ U( A_i ), U( A_j ) ]  = Cov \left[ \frac{1}{\lvert A_i \rvert} \int_{A_i} U ( \mathbf{s}_1 ) \, d\mathbf{s}_1, \frac{1}{\lvert A_j \rvert} \int_{A_j} U ( \mathbf{s}_2 ) \, d\mathbf{s}_2 \right] \\ & = \frac{1}{\lvert A_i \rvert \lvert A_j \rvert} \int_{A_j} \int_{A_i} Cov \left[ U ( \mathbf{s}_2 ), U ( \mathbf{s}_2 )  \right] \, d\mathbf{s}_1 \, d\mathbf{s}_2 \\ & =  \frac{1}{\lvert A_i \rvert \lvert A_j \rvert} \int_{A_j} \int_{A_i} C( \lVert \mathbf{s}_1 - \mathbf{s}_2 \rVert ; \theta) d\mathbf{s}_1 \, d\mathbf{s}_2  = f(A_i, A_j ; \theta). \end{align*}\] First, note Covariance function integral. Implying , manipulations , simply switching order integrals. valid long integrals well defined (equal infinity). Additionally, \(= j\), variance region \(A_i\) \[ Var[ Y ( A_i ) ] = Cov[ Y ( A_i ), Y ( A_i ) ] = ... = \omega + \frac{1}{\lvert A_i \rvert^2} \int_{A_i} \int_{A_i} C( \lVert \mathbf{s}_1 - \mathbf{s}_2 \rVert ; \theta) d\mathbf{s}_1 \, d\mathbf{s}_2. \]

title: 4. Theory
text: Consider process \(\{ U(\mathbf{x}) \,:\, x \D \subset \mathbb{R}^2 \}\) process one defined previous section, region study \(D\). Now, let \(\mathbf{Y}\) p-dimensional random variable observed partition \(D\) defined \(= \{A_1, \dots, A_n \}\). , define \[ Y ( A_i )_k = \alpha_k + U( A_i ) + V_k, \, = 1, \ldots, n, k = 1, \ldots, p, \] \(U \perp V\), \[ V_k \overset{iid}{\sim} N\left(\mathbf{0}, \Omega \right), \] \(\Omega\) covariance matrix (necessarily diagonal matrix). , using similar calculations, \[ Y \sim N( \mathbf{1}_n \otimes \mathbf{\alpha},  \mathbf{J}_p \otimes \Sigma_{} + \mathbf{}_n \otimes \Omega ), \] \(\Sigma_{}\) defined analogously variance covariance matrix univariate \(Y\), \(\mathbf{1}_n\) vector ones, \(\mathbf{J}_p\) matrix ones, \(\mathbf{}_n\) identity matrix.

title: 4. Theory
text: Let \(\{ U(\mathbf{x}) \,:\, x \D \subset \mathbb{R}^2 \}\) (\(D\) whole region study) stationary isotropic Gaussian Random Field covariance function \(C(h; \mathbf{\theta})\), \(h\) euclidean distance two points within \(D\), \(\mathbf{\theta}\) vector parameters controling spatial structure \(U(\mathbf{x})\). Now, let \(\mathbf{Y}\) \(p\)-dimensional random variable observed partition \(D\) defined \(= \{A_1, \dots, A_n \}\) \(\mathbf{X}\) random variable observed different partition space denoted \(B = \{B_1, \dots, B_m \}\). define variables follows \[\begin{equation} \label{eq:model_1} \left \{ \begin{array}{l} Y_{ij} = \alpha_j + \beta_j U( A_i ) + V_{ij}, \, = 1, \dots, n; \, j = 1, \dots, p \\ X_{k} = \gamma + U( B_k ) + T_{k}, \, k = 1, \dots, m; \end{array} \right. \end{equation}\] \[ \begin{array}{l} U( A_i ) = \lvert A_i \rvert ^ {-1} \int_{A_i} U(\mathbf{s}) \, d \mathbf{s} \\ U( B_k ) = \lvert B_k \rvert ^ {-1} \int_{B_k} U(\mathbf{s}) \, d \mathbf{s} \\ V_{} = (V_{i1}, \dots, V_{ip})' \overset{iid}{\sim} N(\mathbf{0}, \Omega) \\ T_{k} = \overset{iid}{\sim} N(0, \tau^2) \\ T_{k} \perp V_{} , \quad T_{k} \perp U, \quad V_{} \perp U, \;  \forall \, = 1, \dots, n, \, j = 1, \dots , m \end{array} \] \(\Omega\) \(p \times p\) matrix entries \(\omega_{ij}\). Now, covariance structure underlying process observed polygons belonging partition \(\) defined \[ ( \Sigma_A )_{ij} = \frac{1}{\lvert A_i \rvert \lvert A_j \rvert} \int_{A_i} \int_{A_j} C(\Vert \mathbf{s}_1 - \mathbf{s}_1 \Vert) \, d \mathbf{s}_2 d \mathbf{s}_2 = f(A_i, A_j ; \theta), \] entries covariance matrix process regions belonging \(B\) given \[ ( \Sigma_B )_{kl} = \frac{1}{\lvert B_k \rvert \lvert B_l \rvert} \int_{B_k} \int_{B_l} C(\Vert \mathbf{s}_1 - \mathbf{s}_1 \Vert) \, d \mathbf{s}_2 d \mathbf{s}_2 = f(B_k, B_l ; \theta), \] \(f( \cdot ; \theta)\) defined similarly. covariance \(Y_{ij}\) \(Y_{'j'}\) \[ Cov(Y_{ij}, Y_{'j'}) = \beta_j \beta_{j'} f(A_i, A_{'} ; \theta), \] Therefore, covariance matrix associated random variable \(\mathbf{Y}\) \[ \Sigma_Y = \mathbf{\beta} \mathbf{\beta}^{\top} \otimes \Sigma_A + \Omega \otimes \mathbf{}_n \, \\,  \mathbb{R}^{(p \cdot n) \times (p \cdot n)}, \] \[ \Sigma_X = \Sigma_B + \tau^2 \cdot \mathbf{}_n \, \\,  \mathbb{R}^{(p \cdot n) \times (p \cdot n)}. \] Moreover, following “cross” covariance relationship \(Y_{j}\) \(X\) entries \[ (D_j)_{ik} = Cov(Y_{ij}, X_{k}) = \beta_j f(A_i, B_k ; \theta), \] \(D_j\) \(n \times m\). Thus, define “cross”-covariance \[ D = \begin{pmatrix} D_1 & \cdots & D_p \end{pmatrix}^{\top} \, \\, \mathbb{R}^{ (p \cdot n) \times m} \] can write joint log-likelihood \[ l_{\mathbf{Y}\mathbf{X}}(\theta) =  l_{\mathbf{Y}|\mathbf{X}}(\theta) + l_{\mathbf{X}}(\theta), \] \(\theta\) vector unknown parameters. \[ (\mathbf{Y} | \mathbf{X} = \mathbf{x}) \sim N(\mu_{Y|X}, \Sigma_{Y|X}), \] \[\begin{align*} & \mu_{Y|X} = \mathbf{1}_n \otimes \mathbf{\alpha} +  D \Sigma^{-1}_X ( \mathbf{x} - \gamma \cdot \mathbf{1}_m)  \, \\,  \mathbb{R}^{p \cdot } \\ & \Sigma_{Y|X} = \Sigma_Y - D \Sigma^{-1}_X D^{\top}  \, \\,  \mathbb{R}^{(p \cdot n) \times (p \cdot n)}, \end{align*}\] come standard theoremos involving multivariate normal (Ravishanker Dey 2020).

title: 4. Theory
text: known literature geostatistics, small scale variance parameters hard estimated due identifiability problems, unless researcher knows, example, ratio variance effect. parameters, considered models, \(\omega\), \(\tau^2\), \(\Omega\). last one properly nugget effect, since can also includes terms covariance variables. Different methods estimation need implemented problem needs examined.

Note , dimension theta_st depends 2 factors. 1) number variables analyzed, 2) input spm object. ... additionnal parameters, either passed optim. model character scalar indicating family covariance function used. options c("matern",     "pexp", "gaussian", "spherical"). theta_st numeric (named) vector containing initial parameters. kappa numeric value indicating either \(\kappa\) paramater Matern covariance function (controlling process differentiability), "pexp" Powered Exponential family. model chosen user Matern kappa informed, automatically set .5. hand, user choses Powered Exponential family inform kappa, set 1. cases, covariance function becomes covalled exponential covariance function. apply_exp logical scalar indicating wheter parameters assume negative values exponentiate . opt_method character scalar indicating optimization algorithm used. details, see optim. control_opt named list containing control arguments optimization algorithm used. details, see optim. comp_hess boolean indicating whether Hessian matrix computed. phi_min numeric scalar representing minimum \(phi\) value look . phi_max numeric scalar representing maximum \(phi\) value look . nphi numeric scalar indicating number values compute grid-search \(phi\).

title: Fitting an underlying continuous process to areal data — fit_spm
text: function uses optim optimization algorithms find Maximum Likelihood estimators, standard errors, model adapted . function allows user input control parameters optim function argument control_opt, named list. Additionally, one can input lower upper boundaries optimization problem, well preferred optimization algorithm (long available optim). preferred algorithm selected argument opt_method. addition control optimization, user can select covariance function among following: Matern, Exponential, Powered Exponential, Gaussian, Spherical. parameter apply_exp logical scalar , set TRUE, \(\exp\) function applied nonnegative parameters, allowing optimization algorithm search parameters real numbers.
code: The model assumes \deqn{Y(\mathbf{s}) = \mu + S(\mathbf{s})} at the point level.  Where \eqn{S ~ GP(0, \sigma^2 C(\lVert \mathbf{s} -     \mathbf{s}_2 \rVert; \theta))}.  Further, the observed data is supposed to be \eqn{Y(B) = \lvert B \rvert^{-1} \int_{B} Y(\mathbf{s}) \,     \textrm{d} \mathbf{s}}.
